Risk Management Plan (Subpart G)
Executive Summary (68.155)
Accident Release Prevention Program and Emergency Response Policy:

It is the policy of facility management to implement the requirements of this Risk Management
Program (RMP) in accordance with the USEPA regulation under 40 CFR Part 68 and with the
corresponding regulations under OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) Program. The
objective is to minimize the risk of a release of a hazardous material and if a release occurs, to
minimize the potential impact to employees, the public and the environment. This objective will be accomplished by utilizing general good operating procedures, providing appropriate training to all employees, and coordinating response activities, as necessary, with the local emergency response providers. Management is committed to providing the resources necessary to implement this policy.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance:

This facility processes raw wheat to produce flour. The raw materials used in the processes are
wheat and chlorine gas. Support operations include a chlorine system, a quality control laboratory, and administrative offices. One chemical is utilized at the facility, in sufficient quantities to be subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68, RMP. The chemical is chlorine and is used to bleach or age the flour.

Worst-Case and Alternative-Release Scenarios:

The Worst-Case Scenario for the Martins Creek, PA location would be a damaged tank valve from the supplier. Each chlorine tank is independent of each other, therefore the loss of multiple tanks at the same time is not considered. This would result in the loss of 1 chlorine cylinder (liquified under pressure) contents of 2,000 pounds released over a duration of 10 minutes.  

The tanks are located inside a storage building designed for chlorine storage, which acts as a passive mitigation technique and limits the release rate to 110 lbs/min. Due to chlorine being a chemical of interest, normal operatin

g procedure only allows keycard access by qualified, trained, and CVI approved Ardent Mills personnel access to the room. Due to security measures, access doors are closed at all times during operations. A urban terrain type was selected as there are many buildings and other obstacles in the immediate area.  

RMP*Comp was used to determine the parameters of the chlorine release, which has a toxic endpoint of 0.0087 mg/l. The predicted radius of the endpoint is 0.9 miles with 1.5 m/s wind speed with wind stability class F. This release is originating from the chlorine storage building, therefore it is used as the center point for the scenario.  

MARPLOT was used to draw the worst case endpoint map.  

The predicted the population within the 0.9 mile radius to be 292 people. The 2020 census data was obtained through the Missouri Census Data Center and used the circular area profile centered on the chlorine storage room.  

Identified public receptors within toxic endpoint were identified as residences and recreational areas. The identified environment receptor within the toxic endpoint is the Delaware River, Lower Mud Run Creek, and Martins Creek 

The Alternative Scenario for the Martins Creek, PA location would be a leak from a 3/8-inch copper flex line that connects the chlorine cylinder to the manifold. This scenario is more plausible than the worst-case scenario based on Ardent Mills operational experience concerning chlorine application systems.  

This scenario encompasses a damaged pigtail with a 3/8-hole expelling chlorine gas at 33.3 lbs. per minute for a duration of 3 minutes.   

The release would be inside the concrete block storage room designed for chlorine storage, which acts as a passive mitigation technique and limits the release rate. Additionally, a couple active mitigation measures are employed: emergency shut off actuators are installed on each chlorine cylinder in service on the tank valve. A chlorine gas detector is installed within the chlor

ine building and will automatically trigger shut off actuators to close each tank valve once a concentration of 4 ppm is detected. Due to chlorine being a chemical of interest, normal operating procedure only allows keycard access by qualified, trained, and CVI approved Ardent Mills personnel access to the building. Due to security measures, access doors are closed at all times during operations.  

An urban terrain type was selected as there are many buildings and other obstacles in the immediate area.  

RMP*Comp was used to determine the parameters of the chlorine release, which has a toxic endpoint of 0.0087 mg/l. The predicted radius of the endpoint is 0.1 miles with 3 m/s wind speed with wind stability class D and an air temperature of 77F. This release is originating from the chlorine storage building; therefore, it is used as the center point for the scenario.  

MARPLOT was used to draw the alternative-case endpoint map. The predicted the population within the 0.1 mile radius is 0.  

The 2020 census data was obtained through the Missouri Census Data Center and used the circular area profile centered on the chlorine storage room.  

Public receptors noted within the toxic endpoint were noted to be residences. The environment receptor within toxic endpoint were identified as the Delaware River. 

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

Employee participation in the release prevention program is encouraged and supported by
management. Key personnel are responsible for conducting and implementing the findings from the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for the chlorine system. Only trained and authorized employees or contractors are allowed to perform work on or adjacent to the chlorine system.

The policy is to construct all new equipment, systems, and facilities in accordance with the most
current building and safety codes, as well as conforming to the recommendations of the Chlorine Institute. This ensures the appropriate s

afety and release prevention systems are included form the beginning of each project. Ardent Mills is committed to providing appropriate training to all employees regarding the safety and health consideration of chlorine. Each new employee is provided comprehensive safety training during his or her initial orientation for the facility. In addition, Ardent Mills conducts annual safety training for maintenance and system operators specific to the handling and maintenance of the chlorine system. 

Five-Year Accident History:

Ardent Mills has not had a release of chlorine that has affected the public or the environment. 

Emergency Response Program:

Due to the proximity of local responders, we have instituted a "No Response" program. That is,
direct contact with appropriate responders is available 24 hours a day, seven days a week. System reviews and emergency action plans have been discussed and reviewed with the local responders and will be reviewed annually for the life of the process. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Ardent Mills, LLC and the Corbion (supplier) complete a thorough review of the chlorine system each time a design change is implemented. The system is also evaluated each time the PHA is revised. We are committed to using these methods to identify and implement ways to improve the safety of the chlorine system.
